The next day, I paid my respects to the emperor and presented my plea with sincerity, requesting a brief return to my hometown to visit my parents and bring them back to the capital to share in this prosperity. I also asked that Liu Shi be recognized as my primary wife. The emperor granted my request and bestowed upon me the privilege of swift travel by imperial post.

Returning to my homeland, I ascended the hall to pay respects to my parents and saw Liu Shi. Before I could even express my thoughts, local officials, old friends, and acquaintances filled the roads, their carriages and hats stretching as far as the eye could see. For over a month, there was no respite. Afterward, I tended to the ancestral graves, held feasts for all my relatives, and spent another month before formally requesting my parents to accompany me to the capital.

Thereupon, my entire family set out together. The journey took over half a month before we arrived at the capital and reached our residence. Lady Wen, leading our two sons, welcomed us joyfully. Upon entering the main hall, she first honored my parents with the highest seat and paid her respects. Next, Liu Shi was seated in the place of honor, receiving the full rites due to a primary wife. Then, my two sons were instructed to pay their respects to their grandparents and their legitimate mother.

A grand banquet was held, with music filling the hall and well-wishers arriving in succession. I shared a feast with Liu Shi to welcome her, and we rejoiced together in the same hall. With golden seals and purple sashes, we enjoyed all the wealth and honor the world could offer.

The emperor specially summoned my parents and elevated them to the titles of Duke and Duchess of Jing. He then urged me to assume my post. I departed the very next day.

A hundred *li* from my post, those who came to welcome me formed a forest of swords and halberds, clouds of banners, lightning-like armor, and ranks of soldiers and horses like scales. After residing at my post for over a month, just as I rejoiced in the peace and stability, urgent dispatches suddenly arrived: the Türks had invaded.

I hastily assembled thirty thousand troops, dividing them into two divisions, and marched out of Yu Pass, arranging them in the Nine Palaces Dark Lady formation. Li Ming served as the left vanguard, Shi Si as the right vanguard, Jia Chong as the scout general, Yuan Hongda as the left rear guard, Zhao Bi as the right rear guard, and Zu Sizeng as the central commander—all formidable generals.

Yet the Türks’ forces were overwhelmingly fierce. Li Ming advanced and said, "Commander, you must not underestimate the enemy. The nomadic cavalry excels in three strengths, while our forces excel in five. However, our five strengths are no match for their three. In the past, Emperor Taizong’s peril at the Muddy River could only be avenged by the courage of three arrows. Today, General, you should defeat them with strategy, as Jiezi captured Loulan or Ban Chao subdued the Western Regions. Victory can be achieved. If you rely on reckless bravery, I fear you will place a thousand *jun* upon a bird’s egg or drive a flock of sheep to chase a tiger—disaster is certain! I beg you to consider this."

I replied, "Have you not heard the maxim of military strategy? Know yourself and know your enemy, and you will never be defeated. Know neither, and you will be defeated in every battle. The extraordinary becomes the orthodox, and the orthodox becomes the extraordinary. First ensure you cannot be defeated, then wait for the enemy’s vulnerability. To seize the initiative with a display of might—this is the mark of a great general. Do you truly believe I do not heed your words?"

Thereupon, I positioned the left flank in ambush in the southeast corner, with soldiers holding wooden bits in their mouths and horses with reins in theirs. I gave the command: "Hide at the sound of the gong, advance at the sound of the fire signal. Li Ming shall lead this."

chunks.translated_text:
The humble and unworthy Minister Lü Yan, Military Commissioner of Henan Circuit, respectfully submits this petition to beg Your Majesty’s grace for leave to retire and care for my parents:

I prostrate myself in awe and reverence, kowtowing to submit this plea. The boundless grace of Heaven blankets all things, and the sagely virtue of the Emperor nurtures and sustains all life. At the dawn of this propitious era, the Son of Heaven, responding to the mandate of the age, governs the world, while wise ministers assist in perfecting the Dao of governance. Yet it is said that loyal ministers are found in the households of filial sons, and those who serve their lord must first fulfill their duty to their parents. The Wei founder acted without principle, leaving Xu You to hold empty worth; the Han emperor, though benevolent, left Wang Mang with lingering regret. Such failures bring no solace to a minister’s heart and only diminish the ruler’s virtue. Let the past serve as a warning, and may the future take heed.

Now, by the grace of Your Majesty, who unites Heaven and inaugurates the era, upholding the world with compassion, teaching filial piety and loyalty, the proper order of human relations is restored. You perfect one’s role as parent and as child, and all virtues are thereby fulfilled. The ancestral temple receives the utmost sincerity, and the memory of the late sovereign is honored with lifelong devotion. The eight directions rejoice in reverence, and the nine provinces exult in harmony.

I, your humble servant, am but a lowly rustic, a mere blade of grass at a humble gate. In youth, I received my father’s teachings and secretly emulated the rules of Confucius; in adulthood, though unworthy, I was entrusted with military command and had the fortune to witness the virtue of Emperor Shun. My labors in service, like those of a warhorse, have been exhausted, yet the rites of caring for my parents remain unfulfilled. In my official duties, I have striven to devote myself entirely—how dare I claim my loyalty is complete? Yet the grace bestowed upon me is boundless, and I long to fulfill my filial devotion. I humbly beg Your Majesty to extend Your vast benevolence, which honors the aged and cherishes the young, and grant me the means to provide for my parents in their final years, like the lamb kneeling to feed or the crow returning to feed its parent. Thus, my sovereign’s expectation of service will not be hindered by my foolish heart, and the twilight years of my parents will have a place of refuge.

I am overwhelmed with gratitude beyond measure. I have instructed my son, Yin, to present this petition for Your Majesty’s consideration. The memorial is respectfully submitted.

May the Emperor not grant my request.

After serving another five years, I was promoted to Military Commissioner of Heyang, where I achieved repeated military successes. My son Yin was appointed to succeed me in Hedao, while I was transferred to serve as Prefect of Yuzhou. I remained in Heyang for eight years, during which both my parents passed away. Though the post was a critical frontier defense, the Emperor did not permit me to observe mourning. One day, urgent reports arrived that the Western Qiang had invaded, allied with the Nüzhen, their combined forces numbering eight hundred thousand. I was in the midst of my parents’ funeral rites when, after a single moment’s delay, the enemy reached the pass. I hastily dispatched He Yan to meet them, but he was captured and beheaded, and twenty thousand of our soldiers were lost. By the time I rushed to the front, the raiders had already fled. The court dispatched five Commandants of the Imperial Guard to bind and escort me to the capital, my wife and children unaware of my fate. I prostrated myself before the Emperor and recounted the circumstances in full. Moved by my past service, the Emperor inclined toward leniency—until slanderous ministers spoke against me, and my execution was ordered. As the blade fell, my spirit scattered ten thousand li, and my entire household was slaughtered to the last soul. I heard my family’s cries, and suddenly awoke—it had all been a dream. The millet was just done cooking. A carefree boy called me to eat, and so I woke.

Alas! A single pot of millet had simmered through thirty years of life—wealth and honor, sorrow and joy, life and death—all no more than this. After the meal, the boy urged me to depart. My heart wavered; I recalled the Quanzhen master’s words and wished to see him once more, yet knew not where he dwelled. I asked the innkeeper, “Have you ever seen a Quanzhen master with a full beard around here?” The innkeeper replied, “Not far from here. Take the forked road, turn at the grove of scholar trees, and walk half a li north—you’ll find a small hermitage. He never strays far.”

I turned back, but the boy resisted. I deceived him by saying I had left my pillow behind, and together we returned to the original spot. As we reached the scholar trees, the Quanzhen master was already seated beneath them; it was the hour of *shen*. He smiled and asked, “Why has the scholar returned?” I answered that I had come to return the pillow. The master said, “If you still wish to sleep, why return it so soon?” Just as I reached to give it back, he turned the pillow aside and fixed his gaze on me: “Do you wish to sleep beneath this tree?” The boy at my side did not want me to rest. The master pointed and said, “Why not take a brief nap while you wait for your master?” The boy promptly fell asleep.

Exhausted, I lay down and slept. Two youths in green robes called my name: “Come, come! Let us take you on a journey!” Unsure who they were, I looked closely and saw they resembled my childhood friend Jin You, and Zhu Jialang, with whom I had shared a bench in youth. I followed them into a pine forest, then through a cypress grove, where the rustling wind sounded like autumn leaves falling, and the stillness was as profound as a midnight road devoid of travelers. Towering bamboo and murmuring springs led us through winding paths into layered passes, up towering cliffs, and down to level ground, until we approached an official residence. Seated within was an official in black robes and a black gauze cap, flanked by attendants who summoned me forward. The official descended the steps to greet me and asked the youths, “Where have you come from?”

chunks.original_text: ”童子附耳密言，其官曰：“诺，诺。 ”忽令一卒，身如金刚，目如虎豹，声如豹狼，身挂青直掇，腰束红绦，头带三山帽，引予而行。 至一所，遇一老妪，白发娑娑，手执磁瓯，唤人饮茶。 予渴欲饮，青年者止之。 又行，遍游爱河，桥广盈尺，高及千丈，波涛汹涌，鱼龙开吻若吞。 或过者化为梁栏稳步，或过者推挤倒溺，鱼龙竟吞食之。 予怆然不忍视； 血湖相近爱河，腥秽之气不可着鼻。 溺河者无男，或止露面，或露乳，或露腹，千百万状。 或提携少儿，或搂抱赤子，红光遍体，人不可近； 刀砧近于血湖，割脐剖腹，开肠剜肚，又加上槌捣砧杵之。 予悲而莫视，青衣嘻嘻笑，强予视焉； 吊竿近于刀砧，较之刀砧少轻，或悬手，或悬足，或手足皆悬。 中以石坠舌出，目眦皆裂。 又加以荆杖加鞭，号楚之声动也。

The youths whispered into the official’s ear, to which he replied, “Very well, very well.” Suddenly, he ordered a soldier—his body like Vajra, his eyes like those of a tiger or leopard, his voice like that of a wolf, clad in a dark green straight robe, a red sash at his waist, and a three-peaked hat upon his head—to lead me onward.

We arrived at a place where an old woman, her white hair cascading, held a porcelain bowl and offered tea to passersby. Parched, I wished to drink, but the youth in green stopped me. We continued on, traversing the River of Desire, its bridge no wider than a foot yet rising a thousand yards high, its waves surging, fish and dragons gaping as if to devour all. Some who crossed walked steadily upon its beams, while others were shoved or toppled into the torrent, where the creatures vied to swallow them. I turned away, unable to bear the sight.

Near the River of Desire lay the Lake of Blood, its stench so foul it could not be endured. Those who drowned here were all women—some with only their faces visible, others with breasts or bellies exposed, in countless grotesque forms. Some clutched young children, others cradled infants, their bodies suffused with crimson light, making them untouchable.

Beside the Lake of Blood stood the Knife and Block, where navels were slit, bellies split open, entrails torn out, and the victims pounded with pestles and mallets. I grieved and averted my eyes, but the green-clad youth laughed and forced me to look.

Nearby hung the Gallows, slightly less severe than the Knife and Block. Some were suspended by their hands, others by their feet, still others by both, their tongues lolling from the weight of stones, their eyes bursting from their sockets. They were flogged with thorned rods and lashed with whips, their cries of agony resounding.

The executioners took it as sport, like puppeteers at play. Near the Gallows stood the Mountain of Knives, its jagged peaks and sheer ridges bristling with blades and halberds, dense as spring bamboo shoots, their silver edges glinting. The guards drove the condemned up the mountain, stripped bare; those who resisted were beaten from behind with great yellow rattan cudgels, forced to crawl upward until their limbs split open and blood gushed forth like springs. I pitied them and begged for mercy, but the guards paid no heed.

Beside the Mountain of Knives lay the Grinding Stone, even more gruesome. The sinners were bound, the upper millstone lifted, and the condemned placed within; the stone was lowered, weighted with boulders, and the victims’ screams shook the earth. Two demons turned the mill while another prodded the flesh and bones with a fork, reducing them to pulp. Blood and pus flowed like slurry beneath the stone.

Nearby stood the Ox-Plow, where sinners were bound with their hands behind their backs. One demon seized their feet, two others pressed a great wooden beam against their backs, forcing out their tongues. Another demon hooked the tongue with an iron curtain rod and stretched it to over ten feet in length, then drove a calf back and forth across it. The tongue, two yards long and three feet wide, was plowed until it turned to mud. Those awaiting their turn were made to watch, their souls shattered in terror.

Beside the Ox-Plow bubbled the Cauldron of Oil, an iron vat like a great urn, filled with boiling oil and stoked with firewood. The sinners were bound only by their feet and lowered into the cauldron; they thrashed with their hands until a demon forced them under with an iron fork. In an instant, flesh and bone dissolved.

Near the Cauldron of Oil lay the Realm of the Hungry Ghosts, a pit holding thousands of sinners, their emaciated bodies no thicker than a span, their throats no wider than a needle. Their heads swelled like bushel baskets, smoke issuing from their mouths, their voices thin as mosquitoes, their forms like turtles or alligators submerged in water—one could not fathom what sins they had committed. The green-clad youth said, “These wretches craved the five pungent foods and the three forbidden meats, never satisfied in life, and so they suffer this retribution. Soon they will be reborn as maggots.”

Beside the Hungry Ghosts burned the Pit of Flames, a trench filled with glowing coals. The sinners’ clothes were stripped away, and they were hurled onto the embers. As they struggled to rise, demons pinned them down with iron rakes, searing their flesh until the stench carried for miles, lingering even a hundred li away.

Near the Pit of Flames stretched the Realm of Darkness, where even in daylight one needed a torch to see. Only the sound of weeping could be heard—nothing more.

Beside the Darkness lay the Realm of Wrongful Death, its walls enclosing countless souls bound by ropes, some missing hands, others feet, some headless or faceless, their forms grotesque beyond measure. All had died unjustly.

Beside the Realm of Wrongful Death stood Avīci Hell, the most dreadful of all. Its gates were barred by tigers, and ranks of ox-headed and horse-faced demons stood guard, allowing no glimpse within. The green-clad youth said, “By the command of the Lord of True Yang, I shall open it for you to see.” The ox-headed demon cracked the gate slightly, and from within came a surge of sinners, wailing and shrieking for help. My heart turned cold, and I turned away.

The youth led me to a hall where I first met the official. He tried to detain me, but I refused. The green-clad youth gave me a push, and I awoke. The master and the carefree youths were gone. The sun had set, and with no place to lodge, I searched for the original inn, but it had vanished without a trace.

The golden wheel of the sun’s chariot had sunk in the western valley, and the jade mirror of the moon hung over the eastern marsh. Before me lay no hostel like Mengchang’s, behind me no estate like Pingyuan’s. Caught between advance and retreat, I wandered, lost in thought. By the roadside stood an ancient pine, its roots gnarled, its branches spreading like a canopy. I leaned against it and sat.

I saw scattered stars like pieces on a half-finished chessboard, the Milky Way like a silken ribbon dipped in a river. A startled magpie cried from the nearby woods, and a few crows winged their way home over the high ridge. From a distant inlet came the creak of a fisherman’s boat returning; from a familiar village, the mournful notes of a shepherd’s flute. I looked around—desolate and alone, my shadow my only companion.

Suddenly, I thought of my parents, who had raised me with such care, always by my side. Now I was lost in this forsaken place, and they knew nothing of my fate. Tears streamed down my face, and I composed a song:

*I gaze at the distant mountains veiled in white clouds,*
*The winding waters of home cut deep into my heart.*
*In the high hall, white-haired, who will tend to them?*
*Neglecting my filial duties, my soul takes flight—*
*O clouds, O clouds, measure my longing across a thousand li.*

Then I thought of my wife, Liu, who had married me still a maiden. She served my parents above and lacked the comfort of children below. Her bed was cold and lonely—all my fault. I composed another song:

*I gaze at the empty valley where a fair one dwells,*
*Spring’s beauty in full bloom, our hearts entwined.*
*Parted like birds with severed wings,*
*I long to soar to the azure skies.*
*Yet in her youth, her mirror gathers dust.*
*Far from home, I shatter her spirit—*
*O song, O song, may the apes not hear my sorrow.*

As I finished singing, my grief deepened. Dark clouds gathered, and the bright moon lost its luster. After a long while, the mist rolled back, and the sky cleared as bright as day. From the southern peak, a white crane descended, its form vast as a wheel. Its cry was almost human as it alighted on the pine, bending its neck to peer at me—seeming to pity me, or perhaps to mock. Several more cranes circled and landed before me, dancing, their feet tracing patterns in the air. With a piercing cry, they joined my song:

*On the southern mountain, white clouds drift,*
*On the northern mountain, white clouds drift.*
*Gazing between them, the heart labors in vain.*
*When clouds gather, heaven seals itself;*
*When clouds scatter, heaven splits apart.*
*Gathering and scattering, parting and uniting—*
*All lies with the heart of heaven.*
*Solid or dissolved, what can man do?*
*Fix your eyes on these clouds,*
*Close them, and they vanish.*
*Parents and children are like these clouds—*
*Though you long to cling to them, you cannot.*

The crane nodded at me: *“Scholar, scholar, which parent does not wish it? But when impermanence comes, they cannot care for you, nor you for them.”*

The crane shook its head and sang again:

*Take that scorched paulownia, craft it into my zither,*
*Pluck its strings once—joy fills my heart.*
*Morning and evening, harmonious union,*
*Play but one tune—the phoenix’s cry.*
*By lamplight and moonlight, side by side we walk.*
*Vowing to grow old together, a hundred years as one.*
*Suddenly the strings snap—silence, soundless.*
*Though I long to play again, the music is not what it was.*
*The phoenix alights on the high ridge,*
*The mirror of the *luan*-bird shatters its water-chestnut frame.*
*Mortal couples are like this zither—*
*Heaven will seize what it will, not to be ransomed even with a thousand gold.*

Again it nodded at me: *“Scholar, scholar, which couple does not wish it? But when the day of fate arrives, each goes their own way. You will not see them, nor they you—where then to seek your spouse? Cut this binding cord at once, and seek for yourself the path of eternal life. When you reach that place, naturally parents and children, husband and wife will know no separation.”*

I was about to question its meaning when the crane stretched its wings, soared into the sky, and returned to the southern peak. The stars shifted beneath the moon, the cock crowed in Fusang, and dawn’s light stirred. My heart suddenly awakened—I no longer wished to press forward. The thought of fame and rank turned to ash, longing for home was severed, and I drifted with thoughts beyond the world, desiring to seek the Perfect Realization as my teacher. Retracing my steps along the old path, I came to the locust grove and sat for a while. There I met a wandering Daoist, his age nearing a hundred years, with snowy hair and bushy brows, clad in a tattered robe, straw sandals on his feet, and a staff in hand. I stepped forward to bow, and we sat together. He asked me: *“From what realm have you come?”*

Amidst the verdant willow grove ahead, a young servant hangs by his life from a high branch.” Startled, my face paled at these words—I knew it must be my runaway page. I immediately wished to go and see, but the Daoist halted, saying: *“Stay, sir. I observe your bones like a solitary crane, your face like spring blossoms, your beard like fresh willow shoots. A dark mole marks your brow, your mountain bones rise firm, your twin orbs gaze toward the sea, your five peaks stand full and proud. Your spirit is clear, your qi fresh—you are surely destined for immortality. Why not follow a master, receive the secret formulas, and seek liberation?”* I bowed deeply to receive his teaching.

The wandering Daoist smiled and said: *“For over thirty years I have roamed, yet never encountered a single true aperture. You should seek elsewhere—do not let this delay your own affairs.”* With that, he turned and departed westward, and though I called, he did not return.

I searched the willow grove and indeed found the boy hanging dead beneath a tree. It seems that while I slept beneath the locust, the master had already left. The boy called to me but I did not wake, so he kept watch through the night. When he realized I would not rise, driven by despair, he wept for me once, then hung my zither and sword in the grove before following me in death.

Alas! Before I could attain the Dao, I first brought ruin to a boy’s life—how can I bear this?

I gathered earth to form incense, bowed toward the empty sky, and swore an oath: *“If I should indeed meet an enlightened master who points out the path of delusion and confirms the mysterious Dao, I shall first deliver this boy. May the gods of heaven and earth witness my sincerity—let not this lonely soul drift far from its root. If I break this vow, may heaven and earth cut short my years.”*

When the oath was complete, I lowered the boy’s body, gathered mugwort from beside the willow roots to cover him, and placed the zither and sword at his side. With earth, I wrote upon the zither: *“To any traveler or dweller who buries this boy, these shall be your reward.”* Then I wept bitterly before taking my leave.

I returned to the locust tree to await the Perfected One’s return, but after two days, no word came. Each day I ate wild fruits to stave off hunger and drank from the stone spring to quench my thirst. My body grew gaunt, my form like withered wood; my feet could no longer walk, my eyes could no longer see. I lay prostrate at the root of the locust tree.

Suddenly, I heard the faint strains of a woodcutter’s song. I strained to listen—its melody was like a tune, the rhythm marked by the strike of an axe handle. The song went:

*“My home lies deep in the mountain wilds,
Axe in hand, I enter the forest thick.
I’ll fell a cypress a thousand years old,
I’ll hew a pine that’s stood ten thousand years.
I care not if he’s a hero or a lord,
I care not if he feasts on golden bowls.
Sometimes I gaze at the moon at zenith bright,
Sometimes I watch the clear wind on the ridge.
Sometimes I dig the white roots of poria,
Sometimes I pluck the red blooms of magnolia.
At dusk, I sleep on the mountainside—
All I gain is a carefree, easy mind.”*

The song faded into the distance. With great effort, I pursued the woodcutter to pay my respects. He asked, *“What brings you, sir?”* I inquired after the Perfected One’s dwelling. The woodcutter replied, *“None here, none at all. Beyond this mountain’s peak, down the other side, stands a dense bamboo grove. Within it is a small thatched hut, where a Daoist lives—jowly, bearded, wild-eyed, barefoot, with a great belly. We call him Master Jin. He’s a Perfected One who’s left the world.”*

I thought to myself: *“When I was still at home, that beggar spoke of ‘a hermitage in Mount Jinzhong.’ Could this be the same man?”* I begged the woodcutter to guide me. He exclaimed, *“Sir, you’re courting death! Why seek that rogue Daoist? Though he’s left the world, he’s fiercer than any layman. When merchants pass by with goods, he doesn’t need to do much—just a single shout, and they’re so terrified they look like little ghosts. I searched the willow grove and indeed found the boy hanging dead beneath a tree. It seems that while I slept beneath the locust, the master had already left. The boy called to me but I did not wake, so he kept watch through the night. When he realized I would not rise, driven by despair, he wept for me once, then hung my zither and sword in the grove before following me in death.

Alas! Before I could attain the Dao, I first brought ruin to a boy’s life—how can I bear this?

He cares not for right or wrong, for all their topsy-turvy ways,

The man said, *“Ah, scholar, you’ve come this far—how bitter it must be! Why not stay at home? Above you, parents; below, wife, children, and servants. As dusk deepened, I could walk no farther and took shelter by the roadside. In an instant, fierce beasts roared, circling around me as if to seize and devour me. Collecting my spirit, I prayed in silence: *“Now, in my quest for life and death, I reck not of body or life. If these beasts hunger, let my flesh fill their bellies.”* A beast crouched before me, its eyes flashing like lightning, its voice thundering like a storm—after a long while, it vanished. Just as I closed my eyes, a bear sniffed at me, its fur scraping my face and brow. It seized my arm with its paw, then reached another into my chest, as if to tear out my heart. I prayed as before, and the bear released me and fled. The night passed without a moment’s peace.

At dawn, my stomach gnawed with emptiness, and my legs would not move. I dug up bracken roots to eat, and with some effort, pressed on. By midday, I saw a shepherd boy tending sheep. I asked how far the mountain hermitage lay, and he replied: *“Not less than ten days’ journey—five to the summit, and five more to the hermitage.”* Undeterred by the distance, I walked on. Parched with thirst, I cupped my hands to drink from a spring and accidentally swallowed a small water snake. My belly twisted in pain. Lying on my back by the stream, crows pecked at my eyes, hawks clawed at my chest, and ants gnawed at my feet. With a single unmoving heart, I endured the agony, though it was truly unbearable. Opening my eyes, I saw the shepherd boy laughing beside me: *“Fool, fool! Where do you think you’ll find Master Golden Heaviness? I’ll lead you back down. Your family awaits your return. Suffer like this, and by tomorrow you’ll have no life left.”*

I pleaded pitifully for mercy. The maidservant’s anger subsided slightly, and she bade me wait. After a moment, she led me inside. A vermilion gate swung open. Within stretched a vast hall of deep chambers, where prawn-shaped hooks hung high and beaded curtains screened peacock-feathered screens. Brocade cushions were spread in rows; aloeswood and sandalwood smoldered in jeweled censers, silver candles flared upon golden stands. As embroidered drapes parted lightly, a fragrant breeze wafted forth. Several maidservants in black led out a young beauty, nearly twenty years of age. Her willow-leaf brows trailed green; her almond eyes shimmered blue. Raven tresses coiled like the morning sun; her powdered face outshone the loveliness of the Luo River goddess. She bore the grace of the Chu palace and the bearing of the Wu kingdom.

She invited me into the hall. I demurred, reluctant to approach the inner chambers of such a noble house. The woman said: *"Since you have come here, it is a bond of three lifetimes, not something fixed in this one alone. You are a young gentleman; I am in the bloom of my years. Heaven has granted our union. Otherwise, how could I dwell in this secluded valley, neighbor to rocks and herbs, companion to deer and swine, where even woodcutters and herdsmen seldom come—let alone a gentleman like you? This is a gift of Heaven, not the work of man."* She called for her maids to prepare a feast.

I prostrated myself in refusal, repeatedly declining, but the woman’s star-like eyes flashed, her willow brows bristled, and her pomegranate teeth clenched. She ordered the maidservants to drive me out: *"Let this starveling scholar be food for wolves!"* I gladly withdrew, but as I did, her anger turned to insistence, and she commanded the doors be locked—though I wished to leave, I could not.

Soon, the feast was ready. She ordered me to take my place. I lingered outside the hall, refusing to enter. Several attendants lifted and carried me in, seating me to her left while she took the right. Before us, a hundred singing boys and dancing girls assembled. With each round of wine, a dance and song followed; the pipes, strings, and drums clamored in my ears, their sound shaking the hills and valleys.

First, they performed *"Cherishing the Hours,"* singing a measured tune. The lyrics went:
*Soft winds stir the brocade chamber,*

*A bird’s cry rings like pipes and strings,*

*Young nobles and ladies,*
*Wandering together to seek spring’s fragrance.*
*Where joy is found, there is the play’s stage—*
*Why seek the Way of immortals beyond this world?*

stirring only vexation and care,

I urge you: cast them away.
Shatter the snare’s scheme,
and only then may you escape life and death.

The four boys sang as they laughed, walked as they sang, then vanished in an instant. I strained to see, but they were gone. Gathering my robes, I pressed onward—already the sun hung low at dusk. Though I stumbled in pursuit, I could not catch them. Turning in every direction, I searched.

Then, atop a sudden rise, on a level stone sat two village boys. Their yellow hair fell to their shoulders, ragged clothes draped their frames. One cradled a handful of stones and two baskets; the other held a stone board, spinning pieces upon its surface. Startled, they stood and bowed in fear.

By then, the moon crowned the pines, bright as daylight. I crossed my legs beneath a sprawling cypress and sat. Soon, two elders arrived with coughs and sighs, settling beside the stone to arrange their stone pieces for weiqi.

One elder called to the yellow-haired boy: “Child, do you know weiqi? Let me tell you of the game.

Weiqi mirrors heaven and earth,
embodies yin and yang’s mutual conquest,
spins in ceaseless transformation,
completes its measured course.
Wield the spirit’s scheme in profound stillness,
birth cunning and skill among peers.
Seize the corners with four or five stones,
claim the borders with slanted plays.
Cast the heron’s long legs,
trap the turtle’s withdrawn head.
A lone army’s deep thrust—
guard against flank-striking pawns.
Troops arrayed in ranks—
require high ramparts and deep trenches.
Illusory eyes: do not treat as live land.
Severed shapes: abandon as dead.
Do not advance and lose your rear,
do not lean right and drift left.
Do not covet bait and lose the fish,
do not indulge in joy and forget sorrow.
To break a formidable foe,
first settle your own strategy.
Open the gate, charge the formation,
watch for gaps to steal in.
Let divine schemes render you unfathomable,
let hidden wisdom make you hard to fathom.
Pursue the plan of ten thousand certainties,
beware the greed for petty gains.
One move amiss—
the whole board is lost.

Like a person in the world,
like a game of weiqi at play:
spread wide, and black and white stretch in every direction;
gather in, and valor and might hide away.
A hundred years pass no swifter than one game,
ten thousand affairs return to a single scheme.
Gaze upon the board and reflect—
I urge you, sir, turn back soon.”

As he finished, I stepped forward to ask a question. The two elders brushed their robes and strode off; the boys gathered the board and followed, vanishing into the distance.

As I stood there in bewilderment, suddenly a great whistle rang out from the northern hollow—like the howling of wind through trees, like the surging of a mountain stream. Two towering black-clad men came charging toward me, their shouts fiercer than Xiang Yu’s, their presence more fearsome than Chiyou’s. One seized my hair, the other my body. Alas, I had no purse! The robbers laughed: “We’ve lurked here for years, but never crossed paths with such a penniless wretch. No money, no clothes—what a waste of our time!” The shorter one grumbled, “I can’t stand this!” Drawing a hemp rope from his waist, he bound me without a word, trussing me like a dumpling in meat. Then they hoisted me high into an ancient juniper, clapped their hands in a triumphant whistle, and vanished into the dense woods.

At that moment, I had no path to heaven above nor earth below, nor any hope of rescue. My limbs burned with pain, and I fainted twice over. Wailing to the empty air, I composed a poem:

*For immortality I sought the Red Pine’s trail,*
*Through brambles and thorns into the mountains deep.*
*How oft my parched throat found the stream’s cool grace,*
*Yet all day my hollow gut knew no grain’s fill.*
*My shoes, worn thin, met jagged peaks’ cruel bite,*
*My tattered robes could scarce withstand the wind’s embrace.*
*Who knew that after dangers past, new perils would arise—*
*Now dangling from this ancient tree, my life nears its last trace.*

I wailed aloud, then fell silent to recite the verse again. Suddenly, a cough echoed from the boulder below. I looked down to see the old weiqi player, gazing up at me with a smile as he chanted:

*Your frame hangs like a withered branch, your body gaunt and frail,*
*Yet fate still tests you with these brutes so cruel and hale.*
*The ropes entangle you as spiders weave their snare,*
*Your shadow sways like a butterfly lured by scent’s sweet trail.*
*They’d have you curl like hedgehog or mantis in retreat,*
*While their wolfish hearts unleash their savagery complete.*
*The flying teal has yet to master life’s elixir true—*
*Why must they shrink your world before its time is due?*

I pleaded for his help. The old man said, “These bandits are vicious—challenge them, and we’ll both be done for.” I begged again. At last, he lowered me down, untied the ropes, and rubbed my limbs, where the bindings had cut deep. Only after a long while did I revive.

“What brings a scholar like you to such a place?” he asked.

I told him my purpose.

“Ah! Ah!” he exclaimed. “You’ve gone astray!”

The tea arrived—clear, cold, and fragrant, its savor one I had not tasted in over a month. When I had finished, a young scholar spoke, asking me the reason for my journey. I answered truthfully. Then all the scholars joined in unison, urging me to stay and pursue the same path: “This place is scarcely a hundred li from the capital. In ten days, the great examination will be held. The master, peering through the moonlight, smiled and said, *"Well gathered, well gathered—now that is a true disciple."*

Since eating the scholars’ tea and rice, I had not felt hunger. Arriving at the hermitage, I was famished, but as the master had not yet eaten, I dared not eat first. Now, after gathering the scattered rice from the ground, I found myself strangely full.

The master said, *"Disciple, tomorrow fetch some water to wash my feet—be early."*

At the fifth watch, I took leave to draw water, but after searching the entire mountain, found none. At a ravine’s mouth, I saw a pool, yet had no vessel to carry it. Using my alms bowl, I scooped a bowlful and returned to the hermitage by noon. The master flicked his hand, spilling it to the ground: *"I told you to go early. Now you bring water at midday—how am I to beg for food? Forget washing. Go beg instead."*

Another night passed. He called for water again. I set out at the fourth watch and returned only at dawn. The master scolded, *"You witless, ailing fool! My feet require a whole vat to wash—would you use this eating vessel for such a task?"* Again, he dashed the water to the ground.

I pondered in vain, then said to the master, *"I have no vessel to draw water, nor one to wash your feet. What if I carry you on my back to the ravine and wash you there?"*

The master hesitated, then replied, *"Very well, but carry me carefully—my feet must not be jostled."*

I helped him lean against my back, cradling his legs in my arms. Four times I stopped to rest. At the ravine’s edge, lowering him proved difficult, so I first knelt, then lay down sideways, easing him to the ground. His rotting thigh rested against mine as I scooped water with my hands, gently wiping away the decay. The foul flesh washed clean, the stench lessened. The master sighed in relief, and I, too, felt joy.

After washing, I carried him back. By late afternoon, as we neared the hermitage, a fierce wind arose—sand flew, stones rolled, the pines roared like raging tides, the ravine echoed like a battle cry. The master trembled; so did I. Suddenly, from the bamboo grove, a thunderous crack split the air as a white tiger leapt forth, its form like a water buffalo, charging toward the master.

I quickly set him down and threw myself over him, pleading to the tiger, *"Eat me instead—spare my master!"* My wails shook the heavens. The tiger paused, then slowly retreated. The wind stilled, the sky cleared. I carried the master back to the hermitage and laid him on his bed.

He turned to me and said, *"Now, at last, you understand my heart."*

The next morning, his feet were healed, and he could rise. One day, he led me to Pine-Plum Ridge. There, pines stood evergreen through the seasons, plums bore the grace of a thousand years. White cranes soared in rivalry, colorful *luan* birds danced in pairs. Fragrant breezes stole upon us, radiant beauty unfolded—another world entirely.

We sat cross-legged on the open ground, the master and I. Knowing my familiarity with letters, he asked me to compose a poem on the pines. I answered at once. The poem read:

chunks.translated_text:
A steadfast soul has long embraced the cold-season’s resolve,
Through endless frost and ice, unbending, never swayed.
Its verdant needles cluster, nourished by the rain’s caress,
Golden pollen sifts like fragrance, scattered by the wind’s embrace.
Roots twist through hidden earth like creatures in deep hibernation,
Its voice pierces layered clouds, roaring like a raging tide.
I charge the woodcutter’s axe: spare wanton felling—
Wait and see it rise as pillars for the halls of heaven’s court.

The master said, *"What you have composed speaks of its use, its outward form, not its transformation. You have yet to grasp what makes the pine the pine—its unyielding integrity, its steadfast constancy. It may offer warmth, it may offer cool, it may endure the snow, yet its rooted foundation remains unshaken. It seizes the essence of heaven and earth, gathers the radiance of sun and moon. Through ages untold, it yields *fuling* from cinnabar caves, works divine wonders among cliffs and peaks, and endures as long as heaven and earth themselves. With the passing of generations, it thrives in lush verdure, soaring to the skies, piercing the clouds—how could its greatness be confined? This is why the pine is revered above all other trees. Do you understand?"*

I bowed my head in acknowledgment and received his teaching.

chunks.original_text: 为赋梅，诗曰： 不逐趋炎一派流，陇头便性自清幽。 香韵暗从风里度，玉肌微向月中浮。 味将浓处鸟偷眠，花欲飞时笛倚楼。 回首群英皆退逊，孰争先后共为俦。 师曰：“是矣。 而梅之不同凡卉，又有在焉。 老于枝，交春再发，冰肌玉骨，经寒不衰，非特不可更植，而本枝终不朽腐。 夺胎投舍，永不绝种。 惟其不逞浓艳，不作繁华，嗜幽间而养天性，故与松竹同侣，而百花凡卉，皆不可及也。 子也如松之坚刚劲直而不染尘埃，茯苓生而胎成实； 如梅之清雅幽闲而不趋红紫，根荄固而子产玉炉，则不但出类拔萃，而长生永世，脱形去壳，终为天地间之完秀矣。 ”予闻之，瞑目默会。 少焉，万虑融彻，诸念一空，洞然反观，见群神现露，茫不觉其所以。 师呼云：“觉乎？ ”予应之云：“方入境，在想象间耳，尚不知其去所也。 ”师微晒曰：“去所不知，来处何觅？ 孔仲尼教仲由之说，记之乎？ 在彼处入境，还有去头。 更寻来头，是你的坯子。 ” 谈久，日落西岩，月升东岭。 师曰：“归哉。 ”予随行。
chunks.translated_text:
To compose on the plum, I wrote this poem:

It does not follow the crowd in warm currents,
But on the ridge, its nature remains serene and secluded.
Its fragrant essence drifts unseen on the wind,
Its jade-like form faintly floats in the moonlight.
Where its scent grows rich, birds steal away to slumber;
As its blossoms seem to take flight, a flute leans against the tower.
Turning back, all other flowers retreat in deference—
Who dares vie with it for precedence or claim kinship?

The master said, "Indeed. Yet the plum’s distinction among common blossoms lies still deeper. Aged upon its branches, it blooms anew with spring’s return. With ice-like flesh and jade-like bones, it endures the cold without fading. Not only can it not be transplanted elsewhere, but its original branches never rot or decay. Through rebirth and renewal, its lineage never perishes. Precisely because it does not flaunt lush beauty nor indulge in extravagant display, but delights in seclusion to nurture its innate nature, it stands as companion to the pine and bamboo, while all other flowers and common blossoms fall short.

You—like the pine’s steadfast strength and uprightness, unstained by dust, bearing *fuling* that forms solid fruit; like the plum’s refined elegance and tranquil seclusion, untempted by crimson and purple, with roots firm and seeds yielding jade censers—will not merely rise above the common, but attain everlasting life, shed your form and husk, and become a perfect essence between heaven and earth."

I heard this and closed my eyes in silent contemplation. After a moment, all cares dissolved, every thought emptied. Inwardly, I beheld a clear vision—spirits manifesting, yet I knew not how. The master called, "Awakened?" I replied, "I have just entered this state, still lingering in imagination, unaware of where it leads." The master gave a faint smile and said, "If you know not where it leads, where will you seek its origin? Recall Confucius’ teaching to Zilu—when you enter a state from without, there is still a point of departure. To seek its origin is to find your own unformed self."

As we spoke, the sun sank behind the western crags, and the moon rose over the eastern ridge. The master said, "Let us return." I followed him.

chunks.original_text: 复抵原庵，则茅塞已开，道路平坦，无复荆榛之碍。 及庵，只见一童子启户迎之。 视童子，即予初入溪路所遇下山之童也。 进庵中，则器用床簟一新，不为土瓦具矣。 师折足坐于榻上，童子焚香于几，点山茗以进，命予坐榻后，对坐焉。 茶毕，童子取玉管吹之，如凤凰鸣于梧桐，环佩击于云汉。 三弄而神清气爽，凡虑一空。 师命瞑重轮闭，心户调橐，苍服虚嘘，转天河于元局，运地轴于黄泥，辟十二之烟关，通九曲之回路。 三百六十五度四分度之一，毫厘为之不差，八八六十四卦以一为八数，氜氜为之不爽。 暑来则寒往，寒往则暑来，互根而见。 动极则归静，静极则归动，迭运而行。 指示既明，功用亦谙。 凡在庵百二十日，镇坐不彻，食予以枣栗，饮予以雨露，予竟忘寝食矣。 一日，师云：“气足矣。 浊者消而清凝者凝矣，人者去而天者复矣。 汝舍诸此乎？ 子归省亲，再来此可也。 ”予愀然恳首：“师何出此言？ 师何出此言？ 弟子并无思也。 家乡永绝，尘事了无，何以归为？ ”师笑而止。 又旬日，与予游翠虚洞。 登峻坡巉峦，险壁危石，松楸满目，鹿鹤成群，紫芝琪树，交错于道。 香风习习，巧鸟锵锵，又一景界也。 异哉，观乎！ 至巅，则平基一方，石凳石几，云霞为幔，嶂列为屏。 与师坐凳上，抚景盘桓，师曰：“人间睹之乎？ ”予对以罕也。 师云：“吾有二师傅约游此，故挈子偕，须待焉。 ” 无何，只见东南松柏深处，隐隐白鹤飞舞前导。 二青衣执拂尘，后二先生。 一短发蓬松，大眼虬须，衣皂袍，系锦丝绦，面黑耳大，身胖而长，跛一足，拄一铁杖，约有五旬。 一瘦骸鹤骨，皓发朱颜，衣白袍，挂蓝衫，头带角巾，束青丝绦，手执如意，约有七旬之上。 皆穿草履，飘飘而至。 相见稽首，跛者坐上位，师坐二位，老者坐三位，命予坐侧。 予稽首，拜叩姓氏。 那跛者掀起虬须，大笑曰：“子记周灵王鞭母事乎？ ”予始知为李柱史也。 方觉此处为仙境矣。
chunks.translated_text:
Returning to the original hermitage, I found the overgrown thickets cleared, the path smooth and unobstructed. Upon arrival, a young attendant opened the door to welcome us. Gazing at him, I recognized the same boy I had met descending the mountain when first entering the valley. Inside the hermitage, all furnishings—utensils, bedding, and mats—were renewed, no longer mere earthenware or tiles.

The master sat cross-legged on the couch, while the boy lit incense on the table and served mountain tea. He bade me sit behind the master, facing him. After tea, the boy took up a jade flute and played, its notes like the phoenix singing in the parasol tree, like jade pendants chiming in the Milky Way. Three melodies later, my spirit felt refreshed, all worldly cares dissolved.

The master instructed me to close my eyes in deep meditation, to harmonize the bellows of the heart, to breathe with the void, to turn the Celestial River within the primordial pivot, to revolve the earth’s axis in yellow mud. He taught me to open the twelve mist-laden gates, to traverse the nine winding paths—three hundred sixty-five degrees and a quarter, not a hairbreadth amiss; the sixty-four hexagrams, each one unfolding into eight, not a single measure awry. When summer came, winter departed; when winter departed, summer came—each rooted in the other. At the extreme of movement, stillness returned; at the extreme of stillness, movement arose—alternating in ceaseless flow.

His guidance now clear, the practice became familiar. For one hundred twenty days in the hermitage, I sat in unbroken meditation, fed only dates and chestnuts, drinking only dew, until I forgot sleep and hunger altogether.

One day, the master said, “Your qi is now full. The turbid has dissipated, the pure has congealed; the human has departed, the celestial has returned. Will you leave this place? Go home to visit your parents, then return.”

I knelt in distress, bowing my head: “Master, why speak thus? Why speak thus? Your disciple harbors no such thoughts. My ties to the world are severed, all worldly affairs resolved—why should I return?” The master only smiled and said no more.

Ten days later, he took me to wander in Emerald Void Cave. We climbed steep slopes and jagged peaks, where perilous cliffs and towering rocks stood amid pines and cypresses, deer and cranes gathered in flocks, and purple mushrooms and jade trees intertwined along the path. A fragrant breeze stirred, and songbirds trilled—another realm entirely. How wondrous to behold!

At the summit, a level terrace appeared, with stone benches and tables, clouds and mist forming its curtains, the surrounding peaks its screens. The master and I sat upon the benches, lingering over the view. He asked, “Have mortals ever seen this?” I replied that few had.

The master said, “Two of my teachers once promised to meet me here, so I have brought you along to wait with me.”

Before long, from the depths of the pines and cypresses to the southeast, white cranes appeared, dancing ahead as guides. Two attendants in blue robes followed, bearing whisk brooms, and behind them, two masters. The first had tousled, unkempt hair, large eyes, and a bushy beard; he wore a black robe tied with a brocade sash, his face dark, his ears large, his body stout and tall. Lame in one leg, he leaned on an iron staff, appearing about fifty. The second was gaunt as a crane’s bones, his hair white, his complexion ruddy; he wore a white robe over a blue gown, an angular cap on his head, and a green silk sash. In his hand he held a ruyi scepter and seemed over seventy. Both wore straw sandals, their forms drifting lightly toward us.

We exchanged bows. The lame one took the seat of honor, the master the second, the elder the third, and I was told to sit beside them. I bowed again, asking their names. The lame one tugged at his beard, laughing loudly: “Do you recall the tale of King Ling of Zhou whipping his mother’s grave?” Then I knew him to be Li, the Grand Historian. Only then did I realize this place was truly a realm of immortals.

A spike struck my crown, and my dreaming soul stirred slightly. I bowed again to the three masters. The elder said, “I was born before the Grand Historian—Zhang Guo of Bohai Prefecture.” I kowtowed once more in deep reverence.

Li said, “Do you know who your master is?”
I replied, “Master Jin Zhong.”
All three burst into laughter, clapping their hands. Li said, “Your master is none other than the Han general Zhongli Mei.”
Only then did I realize that *Jin Zhong* was *Zhong*. Overjoyed beyond measure, I thought: all that I had once heard and recited in tales, I now beheld in person before my very eyes.

The master Li said, “This student is a scholar from Jingzhou. Yet even in the moment of begging alms, he failed to awaken—and now he has endured the toils of years. Have you resolved your mind? I fear that if you falter later, regret will turn to sin.”

I awoke further. The three beggars remained before me, their faces unchanged, though their robes were transformed. Rising, I bowed my head: “With these mortal eyes, how could I recognize the assembled masters? For my past transgressions, I can only beg the heavens’ forgiveness.”

The master smiled: “Now we are one family—what blame remains?” We sat again.
“Li and Zhang wish to discuss the Dao with me. Let us hear your thoughts.”

chunks.original_text: 李曰：“吾与若辈寄踪浮土，寓形块中，坚不如金，植不如树，活泼不如川渊，凝持不如恒岱，随野马之纷纭，等蜉蝣之存没，此其概也。 若夫喜怒哀乐之感，不及花之一荣悴。 穷通得丧之遇，不及时之一寒暑。 翻掌功名，覆掌丘土，又忽尔隙尔，奠可测尔。 故自其形言，天地吾之大者也，吾乃天地之小者也。 自其机言，乾坤一息者也，吾身不息者也。 知身之不息，愈于乾坤之有息。 知其所息，又知其所不息。 则吾身天地，天地吾身，一为三，三为一。 而大者不大，小者不小，无形无机。 万古如斯矣。 ”
chunks.translated_text:
Li spoke: “We and you, fellow sojourners, lodge our traces in floating dust, our forms in clods of earth—hardness not equal to metal, rootedness not equal to trees, liveliness not equal to rivers and deep pools, steadfastness not equal to Mount Tai. Borne along by the wild horses’ tumult, no more enduring than mayflies in their rising and vanishing: such is our general condition.

As for the stirrings of joy and anger, sorrow and delight, they do not match even a flower’s bloom and withering. The vicissitudes of poverty and success, gain and loss, do not match even a season’s shift from cold to heat. Fame and rank turn like a palm’s reversal—graves and mounds, like a palm’s covering—and all too soon, in a flash, they settle beyond reckoning.

Thus, in terms of form: heaven and earth are my greater, while I am heaven and earth’s lesser. In terms of mechanism: the cosmos is but a single breath, while my body is breath unceasing. To know the body’s unceasing breath is to surpass the cosmos’s ceasing breath. To know what ceases, and to know what does not cease—then my body is heaven and earth, heaven and earth are my body, one becomes three, three becomes one. The great is no longer great, the small no longer small, formless and mechanism-less. Thus it has been for ten thousand ages.”

chunks.translated_text:
I rose and inquired into the doctrine of the unceasing. Li requested our master to speak. Master Zhong said, “Listen well, disciple.” With a flick of his palm-leaf whisk, he intoned clearly:

The river’s pulse lies in its source—
no pause in its mechanism,
flowing day and night.
Mighty waves surge from Kunlun’s spring.
No brook is left behind,
flooding all nine provinces.
Bearing the celestial virtue’s grace, no seep nor leak.

This root, discerned in stillness,
is one spring and autumn through ten thousand ages.

Master Zhang struck the fisherman’s drum, rapped the bamboo clappers, and joined in harmony:

Each has its source—
behold it,
flowing on the river’s course.
Luminous pearls roll from Floating Bridge’s spring.
A hundred channels like brooks,
nine bends like provinces.
Stored in the fields, let none be lost.
This root, unblocked, is made alive—
a ceaseless torrent, knowing no autumn.

From his seat, Master Li brandished his ruyi, struck the stone with a resonant *clang*, and joined in:

The ancestral qi is the pass—
issuing from the true source,
flowing day and night.
Pity the long-blocked spring!
Mud clogs these brooks,
filth chokes those provinces.

chunks.translated_text:
After several breaches in the unformed vessel’s leaks,
this root, now pierced through from this day forth,
unfolds in one unbroken autumn’s flow.

The Master asked, “Little one, do you grasp this?”
After a meal’s span of insight, I replied, “I have glimpsed it.”

Masters Li and Zhang said, “If so, you may compose in the same rhyme, that we may gauge your depth.”
I bowed deeply, stood in attendance, and joined in harmony:

On the river’s course, turn not back—
passing thus, like this,
an unbroken stream.
Now the mechanism’s aperture is breached.
Dredged channels, cleared brooks,
linked rivers, opened provinces.
The vast, surging torrent—how could it leak?
Having grasped the root,
its limpid depths run clear,
enduring through ten thousand autumns.

Master Li rejoiced greatly, saying, “This child may be taught, may be taught indeed.
Now I ask you—whence have you come?”
I answered, “From the place of coming.”
He asked, “And what is there?”
I said, “Luminous and unceasing.”
Master Li laughed, “Luminous and unceasing—what is it that moves in this?”
I had no reply.
Master Li said, “Listen to my words:”

chunks.original_text: 本来何处觅行踪。 二五凝成体质融。 日出扶桑红一点，树栽上苑景千丛。 老蚌明珠宁有种，高台宝镜却无容。 套出几多媸美象，寂然境界总空空。 这个实的是他，虚的是我； 有的是他，无的是我； 感而动者是他，寂而不动者是我。 然有个我，必然有个他。 无他，则做了个物，是匏瓜耳。 无我，则做了栽植的样，那里有许多东东西西？ 又煞要他自他，我自我，少他不得，不吃他害。 我自一毫不动，凭他去千番百计做出圈套，我却端严凝重，如大君拱坐于九重，则来者不去，去者尽是他。 认得这个来的路头，则去的路也不错，原处来，原处去。 如此，则要来也是我，要去也是我，那个拘管得我着。 要上天也由我，要入地也由我，要小也由我，要大也由我，那一个束缚得我定。 如今世上人，从这条路上来。 始初间走不远，还认得这路数些子儿。 看看走到广途大境，人多之处，就忘记了。 急急回转，还不甚差远路。 岂知被那途中最致，许多炫耀，夺目诱心，朝勾暮引，赁得一间房儿住着，积得许多金宝，恰好做个人家。 那六贼钻穴逾墙，百般巧计来思量偷盗，不搬尽了家财，不肯休歇。 弄到一个贫穷汉子，房儿破损。 朝为轻风穿户，暮当细雨飘窗，垣塌墙崩，梁摧柱折。 他那哄诱我的，抛我自去，我却无处安身。 欲寻来的原路回去，都是茫茫渺渺的所在，那里认得。 无可奈何，只得东支西吾，随着个去处，就安了身。 也不管好歹，也不管安佚，可以放下身子便罢。 甚至被他拖下钱债，结下冤仇，东不肯收，西不肯留，南边要骂，苦楚万端，狼狈特甚。 只得寻个草堆，土垣中安歇，越走差了路，与那来处原所在，如隔华夏，再也不认得回去，岂不可怜可怜。 这个都是吃他的亏，吃他的害。 故此要我自做主张，寻访来头。 便是返本还原，归宗复祖。 乾坤我的住居，阴阳我的夫妇，日月我的灯炬，江湖我的杯斝，恒岳我的土块，风云我的发舒，雨露我的津唾，何以始？ 何以终？ 何以来？
chunks.translated_text:
Where was the trace ever found in the first place?
Two and five congeal to form the harmonious body.
At sunrise, a single red gleam from Fusang’s boughs—
a thousand groves of splendor planted in Shangyuan’s gardens.
The aged clam’s bright pearl—how could it have a seed?
The lofty terrace’s precious mirror—yet holds no form.
How many fair and foul images are cast forth,
while the serene realm remains utterly empty.

What is real belongs to him; what is illusory belongs to me.
What exists belongs to him; what is nonexistent belongs to me.
What is stirred by feeling belongs to him; what is still and unmoved belongs to me.
Yet if there is this “me,” there must be that “him.”
Without “him,” one becomes a mere thing, a dried gourd.
Without “me,” one becomes a planted pattern—where then are all these scattered things?

Thus, he must be himself, and I must be myself;
he cannot be dispensed with, yet he does no harm.
I remain utterly unmoved,
while he devises a thousand schemes and a hundred snares.
Yet I sit in solemn dignity, like the great sovereign enthroned in the ninefold palace—
what comes does not depart; what departs is entirely his.

Recognize the path of what comes,
and the path of what goes will not err:
from the original place it comes, to the original place it returns.
Thus, to come is of me, to go is of me—
who could restrain me?
To ascend to heaven is by me, to enter the earth is by me,
to be small is by me, to be great is by me—
who could bind me fast?

Now, the people of this world come by this very path.
At first, they have not gone far and still recognize some of its signs.
But as they press on into vast realms and crowded places,
they forget entirely.
If they turn back in haste, they have not strayed too far.
Yet they know not that along the way, countless enticements
dazzle the eye and beguile the heart,
luring them by day and drawing them by night.
They rent a dwelling, amass gold and treasures,
and just as they settle into a household,
the six thieves scale walls and burrow through holes,
devising every cunning scheme to steal away their wealth,
not ceasing until their home is stripped bare.
Reduced to destitution, their house in ruins—
by day, the light wind whistles through the door;
by night, the fine rain drifts past the window.
Walls collapse, beams crack, pillars snap.
Those who once beguiled them now abandon them,
leaving them nowhere to rest.
Seeking the original path to return,
they find only boundless, indistinct places—
how could they recognize it?
Helpless, they drift east and west,
settling wherever they may,
heedless of good or ill, comfort or hardship,
content to lay down their burden and be done.
Even then, debts and enmities drag them down,
no one in the east will take them in,
no one in the west will keep them,
while the south reviles them.
Suffering in a thousand ways, utterly wretched,
they can only seek shelter in a haystack or a crumbling wall,
each step leading them further astray,
so far from their origin that it might as well be the Central Plains—
never again will they find their way back.
How pitiful, how pitiful indeed.
All this is the harm he inflicts, the ruin he brings.

Thus, I must take command of myself,
seek out the source of my coming—
this is to return to the root and revert to the origin,
to return to the clan and restore the ancestry.
Heaven and earth are my dwelling,
yin and yang my husband and wife,
sun and moon my lamps,
rivers and lakes my cups,
the eternal mountains my clods of earth,
wind and clouds my unfolding,
rain and dew my saliva—
how did it begin?
How will it end?
From whence did it come?

chunks.translated_text:
Whence does it go?
What is life?
What is death?
Surveying Qin and Chu, observing the gains of rivals,
glimpsing the foolishness of Chiyou and Xiang—
all this is but a laughing matter.
What then of gain and loss?"

I asked, "May I dare inquire what method brings one to this state?"
The master replied, "The techniques differ, and so too their returns to the origin.
One must interweave and cross-examine,
seeking the utmost, the most profound, the subtlest, the deepest—
only then is it refined.

Let me explain to you:
Those who dine on pine needles and consume elixirs
cannot swiftly transcend;
life and death are fixed in their breath—
how can they forget form?
Focusing on the hundred meridians,
visualizing the cinnabar field,
regulating breath to a thread—
yet the fetal state remains unformed.
Holding breath and concentrating thought,
perceiving the profound silence of the primordial—
still, in the end, they fail to ascend.
Those who take the mouth and nose as the Mysterious Female
are like wind trapped in a net.
Those who regard the square inch as the heart’s field
see the ancestor but forget the clan.
If one accumulates essence as celestial lead,
the cinnabar and mercury remain incomplete.
Treating spirit and qi as mother and child,
the terrace of immortality lies far beyond.
Opening the crucible for refinement,
labor is spent in vain;
refining mercury and balancing tortoises—
these are but perverse and deluded arts.
Three years, nine cycles—
how can the firing time suffice?
Holding breath to absorb the primordial,
the yin wind howls in response.
Those who recognize mind and see nature
may have a head, yet end as spectral beings.
Sitting at midnight and noon—
though this is effort, it is but rigid and constrained mystery.
Is the tongue truly the Crimson Dragon?
Eyes closed like a fox’s breath—
the crown as the Yellow Court,
the kidneys as creation—
mired and unpenetrated.
The tail palace as life,
the foot apertures as the source—
substance without transformation.

More still: consuming water and fire to return to the origin—
the path of error grows ever wider.
Absorbing essence through dual cultivation,
the road of entry strays further.
Gazing at the heavens to draw in the essence of sun and moon,
disregarding celestial soul and earthly spirit—
a single meal spanning day and night,
only to invite emaciation and frailty.
Curving the body, lying prostrate,
knocking the five gates to sound a long cry—
what benefit is there?
The Way of inner cultivation lies in guarding the primordial and embracing the One.
Turning the twin pupils inward to reflect—
this too is not the near path.
The gate of the oral formula:
raising the shoulders, craning the neck,
circulating the spine’s flow—
the hundred meridians may open, yet one aperture remains dim.
Inscribing talismans, chanting incantations,
pledging contracts in clear words—
the hundred evils may be dispelled, yet one spirit is obscured.
Worshipping the Dipper, gazing at stars—
labor spent in vain, no aid to sighing.
Massaging and pressing, practicing arts—
what merit in such methods?
The talk of exhaling turbid and inhaling pure is crude;
the discourse on eating plain and fasting is base.
Holding registers and performing rites,
setting up altars—
all devoid of virtue.
Using bellows and keys to gather essence and coalesce spirit—
only to fall into the path of transgression.
The ancestral qi of the primordial
does not reside in form, image, or imitation;
the sacred medicine of the Great One
how could it depend on smelting lead or refining mercury?

Transcending the realms of the multitude,
awakening to the formless within the formless;
entering the Mysterious Pass,
discerning the auspicious within the existent.
Unfolding the lotus within fire,
drawing forth the pearl from water.
In the cauldron of dragon and tiger,
no need to seize—naturally subdued;
in the furnace of tortoise and snake,
no need for forging—silently refined.
In movement,
true stillness without motion;
in emptiness,
firmness without void.
There is something prior to heaven and earth,
formless yet within the unshaped embryo.
A voice in the valley echoes through a thousand mountains;
waves on the river stir a hundred seas.
So many afflictions—
unrelated to these myriad endeavors,
heedless as withered wood.
Yet when spring dew touches the withered,
it revives like dead ashes;
when fire and wind scatter the ashes,
one recognizes the magpie’s chariot ascending layered heavens.
The fluid of the jade elixir congeals in the Crimson Palace.
Why must the Yellow Dame mediate marriage?
Why must the Infant be nurtured to completion?
Drawing from Kan to fill Li,
mending the torn patch of the monk’s robe;
Qian revolves, Kun turns—
rebuilding the crumbled walls.
Those who probe the Mysterious Pass of a single aperture
cling to deluded views;
those who point to the nine-fold elixir method
hold shallow discourse.
Riding the golden ox to roam the eight wilds,
reversing the Yellow River through the three barriers—
all are but dust with traces,
not the supreme vehicle of the formless.

Within the twelve hours, it is qi;
within the chest, it is spirit.
If one merely wanders among a hundred paths and thousand byways,
in the end, one flows into the realm of gods, demons, and ghosts—
able to seize a vessel, yet also to be reborn.
Nine revolutions, ten transformations—
if one can transcend the mundane,
then one can enter sagehood.
A single surge spanning a thousand leagues—
know that refining stone can mend heaven,
then believe that ascending clouds enables transformation.
This living, vibrant thing,
like a rolling pearl upon the earth;
this radiant, luminous thing,
outshining the bright moon in the sky.
Unmired in stagnation,
unobscured by dimness—
seeing through the mechanism of the aperture,
leaping beyond the gate of life and death.
Heaven and earth share my rise and fall,
the cosmos my duration and transience.
Unbreakable, unseverable,
unscorched by fire, undampened by water.
Though the seas overturn and rivers surge,
the heart does not dance, the spirit does not stir.
This is the most profound mystery,
yet not a matter of many techniques.
One’s own affair must be sought by oneself—
to ask another is already error.
Coming by one path,
going by one path—
to stray elsewhere is to lose the way.

You have affinity; how could I remain silent?"
Having spoken, two youths bore platters of fruit, nuts, and wine cups,
arranging them upon a flat stone.
I bowed in gratitude for the instruction and bade him sit again.
Gazing upon the spread:
peaches like great bowls,
lotus roots like flat boats;
the pears of Hebei surpassing,
the jujubes of Jiaozhou exceptional;
melons large as cauldrons,
oranges brimming with chess pieces.
As if simmering dragon’s liver—yet the flavor more exquisite;
as if stewing phoenix’s wing—yet the form unlike.

sun and moon my lamps,
rivers and lakes my cups,
the eternal mountains my clods of earth,
wind and clouds my unfolding,
rain and dew my saliva—
how did it begin?
How will it end?
From whence did it come?

chunks.original_text: 鹤脯不缘于制，鸾胎岂于烟成； 猩唇不假于猩，豹髓不取于豹，琼浆玉液，侵琥珀玻璃； 麻菇青精，味拂苍穹碧落。 劝酬良久，有白鹤青鸾群舞，低昂中节，俯仰有度，翩翩过于八冈，雍雍然愈于七德。 舞毕，分立左右。 数青表小童序列于下，击节以歌。 其一歌曰： 二气呼吸兮，谷有声。 扫千山之落叶兮，开九漠之阴云。 寻之无影兮，察之无形。 忽然而寂兮，忽然而存。 不可以迹拘束兮，又难乎其与行。 勿疾而速兮，勿存而神。 从茂林而舒首兮，从啸虎而即生。 开我襟而一披拂兮，殆觉思爽而神清。 其二歌曰： 得乾坤之丽气，独盛于阳春。 得化工之巧制兮，独媚于晴明。 装千红与百紫兮，斗枝上之奇英； 蕴清芬与秀质兮，吐芳心之秾馨。 恁狂蜂之乱扑兮，不断其精； 由浪蝶之纷扰兮，弗丧其真。 培根蒂之坚固兮，实而复生。 历岁月而恒久兮，霜露高擎。 其三歌曰： 如二气之氤氲兮，万物化醇。 弥得清宁兮，上下纷纭。 遍六合以飞旋兮，不同野马之奔腾。 覆九有以庇护兮，不惜雕琢之琼英。 散则可以无管束兮，聚则可以成形。 炼阴魄以布两间兮，化阳神而卒莫知其所存。 妙变化以不定兮，喜僧舍与旗亭。 何以为此肤骨兮，乃鹇羽而鹤翎。 其四歌曰： 秉此阴精兮，映乎太阳。 耿耿不昧兮，灼灼口光。 似龙吐于宝珠兮，滚出乎汉洋。 丽中天而常明兮，清晖之独扬。 无一物之不烛兮，如析是非之智囊。 无一处之不及兮，如敷惠德之圣玉。 羡灵台之一点兮，历万古而如寻常。 有盈虚而无止息兮，觉乎斯世之蒙盲。 众童歌阕，为之奏逍遥乐。 金笙、玉管、凤笛、龙箫，锦瑟之和冰弦，玉板之调花鼓。 高声如九皋唳鹤而彻层霄，低声如万壑细泉而流重涧。 其音或徐，有如尧行舜步，揖逊于庙廊之间； 其音或疾，有如单牛羽骑，驰逸于行伍之内。 或时翕然而并奏也，如群工列辟，当会同之期而莫敢于天子。 或时敛焉而步间也，如洋洋圉圉，当万苏之顷，而未免鳞尾之停摇。 加之以鹤舒颈而和，鸾鼓翅而鸣，凤调舌而作声，鹦清喉而步韵，倾耳之下，不觉神飘兴荡，心醉情怡，忘天地之高深，泯人己于俱乐，不容述也。 乐终，二鹤向前昂首，作言吐音。 歌出道情。 词曰：
chunks.translated_text:
The crane’s breast needs no preparation,
the phoenix’s embryo forms not in smoke;
the ape’s lips require no ape,
the leopard’s marrow no leopard.
Jade nectar, liquid gem—
seeping into amber and glass;
mushrooms of hemp, essence of greens—
their savor brushing the azure vault and jade firmament.

After long toasts, white cranes and green phoenixes danced in flocks,
their rises and falls keeping time,
their bows and lifts measured.
Gracefully they passed beyond the eight ridges,
their harmony surpassing the seven virtues.
When the dance ended, they stood in ranks to left and right.
Several green-robed youths arranged themselves below,
beating time as they sang.

The first song:
The two qi breathe in and out—
the valley echoes with sound.
Sweeping a thousand mountains’ fallen leaves,
parting the nine deserts’ gloom.
Seek it—no shadow;
observe it—no form.
Suddenly still,
suddenly present.
Not to be bound by traces,
nor easily companioned on the way.
Not swift yet swift,
not present yet numinous.
From the dense grove it lifts its head;
from the roaring tiger it springs to life.
Opening my robe in one sweep,
I feel my thoughts refreshed, my spirit clear.

The second song:
Receiving the radiant qi of Heaven and Earth,
it flourishes in spring’s fullness.
Receiving the Craftsman’s artful touch,
it charms in bright clarity.
Adorning a thousand reds and a hundred purples,
it vies with the branches’ rare blossoms;
nurturing pure fragrance and graceful essence,
it exhales a heart of rich perfume.
Though wild bees madly dart,
its essence remains unbroken;
though wanton butterflies swarm,
its truth is not lost.
Its root and stem stand firm,
bearing fruit again and again.
Through years and months it endures,
lifting high through frost and dew.

The third song:
Like the two qi’s subtle blending,
the myriad things transform in harmony.
Pervading all with clarity and peace,
above and below in profusion.
Spanning the six directions in flight,
unlike wild horses’ headlong rush.
Covering the nine lands in shelter,
unmoved by carved jade’s splendor.
Scattered, it needs no restraint;
gathered, it takes form.
Refining yin’s spirit to fill the space between,
transforming yang’s spirit—none know where it abides.
Wondrously shifting, never fixed,
delighting in temple halls and tavern signs alike.
What makes this flesh and bone?
Only silver pheasant’s plumes and crane’s feathers.

The fourth song:
Holding this yin essence,
it reflects the great yang.
Bright and unwavering,
radiant with light.
Like a dragon spitting a jewel,
rolling forth from the Milky Way.
Adorning the mid-heaven with constant brilliance,
its pure glow alone shines.
No thing remains unillumined—
like a treasury of wisdom to discern right and wrong.
No place is left untouched—
like a sage’s jade dispensing kindness.
Enviable, that single spark in the spirit’s terrace,
through ten thousand ages unchanged.
Though waxing and waning, it never ceases,
awakening this benighted world.

When the youths’ songs ended, they played the *Xiaoyaoyue*.
Golden sheng, jade pipes, phoenix flutes, dragon xiao,
silk se zither harmonizing with ice strings,
jade clappers keeping time with flower drums.
The high notes soared like cranes crying over the nine marshes,
piercing the layered clouds;
the low notes flowed like ten thousand ravines’ fine streams,
cascading through deep gorges.
At times slow—like Yao pacing, Shun stepping,
bowing and yielding in the ancestral hall;
at times swift—like a single ox or feathered rider,
racing through the ranks.
Sometimes swelling in unison—
like officials arrayed at court,
daring not overstep before the Son of Heaven.
Sometimes restrained, stepping in measure—
like a vast herd at pasture,
when all things revive yet scales and tails still pause.

Then the cranes stretched their necks to join,
the phoenixes flapped their wings and sang,
the phoenix tuned its tongue to sound,
the parrot cleared its throat to follow the rhythm.
Listening intently, one felt the spirit soar and the heart sway,
drunk with joy, forgetting the vastness of heaven and earth,
blurring self and other in shared delight—
beyond words.

When the music ended, the two cranes stepped forward, raised their heads,
and spoke in song, voicing Daoist sentiments.

arranging them upon a flat stone.
I bowed in gratitude for the instruction and bade him sit again.
Gazing upon the spread:
peaches like great bowls,
lotus roots like flat boats;
the pears of Hebei surpassing,
the jujubes of Jiaozhou exceptional;
melons large as cauldrons,
oranges brimming with chess pieces.
As if simmering dragon’s liver—yet the flavor more exquisite;

chunks.original_text: 碧云庵，远市朝。 纤尘飞绝真幽俏。 千株翠柏参金桂，几树琪花间碧桃，玉莲池内香风绕。 你看古砌重台，凤尾交灵芝，满径多瑶草。 四时无谢花，千岁松何肴。 这其间有许多景物，乐趣陶陶。 又歌曰： 浅浅溪，小小桥，岩头落涧琼珠倒，红霞灿烂铺山娇，皎月团圆挂岭梢，鸟鸣枝梢人踪杳。 你看石凳松阴石子敲，那知烦渴和饥饱。 天空鸢阵飞，波静龙旋绕。 这其间有无穷乐意，真个逍遥。 歌罢，与数鹤鼓翘，跃足耸颈，左盘右转，俯仰伸屈，万态千状。 飞蹈一回，划然长鸣，声振九皋，遏飞云，彻霄汉，令人心旷意驰，神清气畅。 三师大饮巨觞，开怀酬对，方辰五申，殆不知其世之几易月日矣。 杯盘已残，肴核将尽，其李、张谓曰：“今日之会，为吕生开一窍也。 可以脱，可以化，即可与偕至，毋滞时岁，以失事期。 ”钟师唯唯。
chunks.translated_text:
The Azure Cloud Hermitage, far from the bustle of towns and courts,
where fine dust never rises—truly secluded and serene.
A thousand emerald cypresses stand among golden osmanthus,
a few jade-flowered trees interspersed with crimson peaches,
while fragrant breezes swirl around the lotus pool.

Behold the ancient steps layered in tiers,
phoenix-tail ferns entwined with sacred lingzhi,
and jade-like herbs carpeting every path.
Flowers bloom in all four seasons, never fading,
while thousand-year pines stand firm and proud.
Amid such scenes, countless vistas unfold,
and joy overflows like wine.

Again they sang:
A shallow stream, a humble bridge,
where jade-like pearls tumble from cliffs into the ravine,
crimson clouds dazzle, adorning the mountains in splendor,
a bright moon, full and round, hangs at the ridge’s peak,
while birds sing in the branches and human traces vanish.

Behold the stone benches beneath pine shade,
where pebbles are tapped in rhythm,
oblivious to thirst or hunger.
In the empty sky, kites soar in formation,
on calm waters, dragons coil and glide.
Here, boundless delight unfolds—
true freedom at last.

The song ended, and with several cranes, they flapped their wings,
leapt and stretched their necks, circling left and right,
bending low and rising tall—
a thousand postures, ten thousand forms.
After their dance, they let out a piercing cry,
their voices shaking the nine marshes,
halting the flight of clouds,
resounding through the heavens,
leaving one’s heart unbound and spirit soaring,
mind clear and qi flowing.

The Three Masters drank deeply from great goblets,
their hearts open in mutual toast,
as the hours passed—
unaware how many days and months of the world had slipped by.
When cups and plates lay empty,
and dishes were nearly bare,
Li and Zhang spoke:
“Today’s gathering was to open a passage for Master Lü.
You may transcend, you may transform—
come with us now,
do not linger through the years,
lest you miss the appointed time.”

Master Zhong assented in agreement.

chunks.original_text: 李、张顾予曰：“子坚持坚持，速悟速悟，吾候子也。 ”即跨鹤望西而去。 予怅望久之，已喜其从仙游矣。 第师尚未挈同行，怀闷虑耳。 师曰：“二先生已去，吾与若盍往庵乎？ 今日之会乐乎否？ 子能不以乐为乐而不以忧为忧，不以聚为聚而不以散为散，祝我而彼之，祝彼而我之，斯乐其乐而我自若，忧其忧而我自休，聚者聚而我无系，散者散而我无放，是实实而空空，空空而实实也。 言言行行，子皆不可饶过去了。 ” 予受旨抵庵，与师居，事礼无二。 恭心克一，严祗之忱，日新时茂。 日则共师谈诀于松阴竹覆之下，夜则参玄于冥思默想之间，见本来面目之真容，破三昧七盗之妄像。 万丈潭中，跳出双睛五虎，一坑火内，长起九吊金莲。 圆珠盘上走，六剑匣间开。 混混沌沌，露现胚胎。 萌孽烦烦扰扰，澄澈浊浪浑波。 不有而不不有，不空而不不空，果是作为成幻象，信然光朗乃真机。 傀儡场前，枉自牵丝拽线，陶冶手里，空劳铸铁熔铜。 有迹之真都是假，无形之假总成真。 到此处，猛火炉中飞片雪，沸汤釜里下毫冰。 舍屋时空，几度出游于六合，墙垣枉立，数番觔斗上三台。 存即神，念即化，不俟搜求，无劳摩揣。 师知予行到功满，一日，呼谓之曰：“无者，本来已见。 有者，本来当知。 从故道而复归故乡去来。 子向于蒲阴村遇吾之师，曾为逸童立誓。 今彼堕于凶道，子当授以诀法，度其归山，速便回庵，莫为尘累，迷此前途。 ”当日即以拂尘、盂瓢授予。 予领之拜别，乘清风直往活水村来，乃化作一乞食道者，往来于途。 寻访竟日，父母已殁。 惟刘氏守节为尼，家宅易为道院，正同一二老尼，诵经于大士前。 予径入，尼叱之曰：“此乃女庵，清净戒院。 何方道者乃男子，安可则进？ ”予稽首受罪，上扣道众：“贫道远方山野，不知礼法，冒犯仙庵。 但同为出家人，僧来看佛面。 贫道外无遮体之衣，内乏充肠之食，兼以知识又少，人生路生，特求仙庵驻足，抄化衣食。 旬日之间得遇善信达长，自当酬谢还山。 伏望开普济之门，弘度人之德，不以山野推阻。 足感仙慈。
chunks.translated_text:
Li and Zhang turned to me and said, “Hold firm, hold firm—awaken swiftly, awaken swiftly. We await you.” Then they mounted their cranes and departed westward. I gazed after them in longing, heart gladdened that they had joined the immortals’ journey. Yet my master had not taken me along, and this weighed heavily on my mind.

The master said, “The two gentlemen have gone. Why not return to the hermitage with me? Was today’s gathering joyful? Can you find joy without clinging to joy, and ease without being troubled by sorrow? Can you meet without attachment to meeting, and part without resistance to parting? Bless them as yourself, bless yourself as them—then their joy is your serenity, their sorrow your repose. Those who gather are bound, yet you remain free; those who scatter are lost, yet you stay unburdened. This is the solid within the empty, the empty within the solid. In every word and deed, you must not let a single moment slip by.”

I received his teaching and returned to the hermitage, where I served him with unwavering devotion. My reverence was single-minded, my devotion earnest, ever renewed and flourishing. By day, we discussed secrets beneath the shade of pines and bamboo; by night, we delved into the profound through silent contemplation, glimpsing the true face of our original nature and shattering the illusions of the Three Mysteries and Seven Thieves. From the depths of a ten-thousand-foot abyss, a pair of eyes and five tigers leapt forth; within a pit of fire, nine golden lotuses bloomed. A pearl rolled across the plate, six swords unsheathed from their caskets. Chaos gave way to the first stirrings of life—budding, restless, then settling into clarity, the muddy waves stilled. Neither being nor non-being, neither emptiness nor non-emptiness—truly, all actions are but phantoms, while radiant truth lies in stillness. Before the puppet stage, strings are tugged in vain; in the foundry’s hands, iron and bronze are melted to no purpose. The tangible is false, the formless is real. Here, a flake of snow flies in the furnace’s fierce blaze, a hair of ice descends into the boiling cauldron. The house is left behind, empty—several times I roamed the six directions; walls stood in vain—countless somersaults carried me to the Three Terraces. To exist is to be spirit; to think is to transform. No need for search, no labor for conjecture.

Knowing my practice had reached fulfillment, the master called to me one day: “The formless has already revealed itself. The formed is yet to be known. Return along the ancient Way to the old homeland. Once, in Puyin Village, you met my master and vowed to become a carefree youth. Now he has fallen into an inauspicious path—you must teach him the secret method, guide him back to the mountain, then swiftly return to the hermitage. Do not let worldly dust entangle you or obscure the road ahead.”

That day, he entrusted me with a whisk and a begging bowl. I received them, bowed in farewell, and rode a pure wind straight to Huoshui Village. There, I transformed into a mendicant Daoist, wandering the roads. After a day of searching, I learned my parents had passed. Only Liu-shi remained, having kept her chastity as a nun; the family home had become a Daoist abbey, where she and a few elderly nuns chanted sutras before the bodhisattva’s image. I entered directly, and the nun scolded me: “This is a convent, a pure and precept-bound sanctuary. How can a male Daoist simply barge in?”

I bowed my head in apology and addressed the assembly: “This poor Daoist comes from a distant mountain wilderness, ignorant of proper conduct, and has trespassed upon your sacred abbey. Yet as fellow renunciates, when a monk comes, you see the Buddha’s face. I have no clothes to cover my body, no food to fill my stomach, and few acquaintances in this world. Seeking refuge in your abbey, I humbly beg for alms of clothing and food. Within ten days, should I encounter a generous patron, I will repay your kindness and return to my mountain. I implore you to open the gate of universal salvation, to magnify the virtue of delivering others—do not turn away this mountain dweller. Your compassion will be deeply felt.”

chunks.translated_text:
The chief seat glanced at me and ordered the manager: “Give this Daoist a liter of alms-grain and send him on his way to find lodging elsewhere. Though this is but a small abbey, it is a private residence, and moreover filled entirely with women—how can we accommodate a man? It would not be proper.”

I refused the alms-grain and made a bow to the chief seat: “Venerable one, venerable one, I came to this sacred abbey for a reason. If you will not permit me to stay, and I am given alms-grain, who will cook it for me? If you would but lend me a young brother to keep me company, I will leave at once. If you refuse, I will remain here and never step outside for a thousand years.”

Hearing this, the chief seat flushed crimson and flew into a rage, cursing: “This wild Daoist is utterly without manners! This is a sanctuary of the Buddha’s disciples, a pure Dharma-gate—how dare you spout such nonsense here! You are no madman who has lost his senses, yet you utter such reckless words. If you do not leave at once, we shall deal with you by the Dharma’s principles.”

I laughed and said: “Fine nuns, fine nuns—you speak of leaving the household and purity, but where is your purity to be seen? You have not even renounced the south, yet you presume to become Buddhas? Listen to what I tell you: that Amitābha is no trifling secret.”
